unnormalised: The summer of '08 was a scorcher, and not just weather-wise. Papa, usually the picture of calm as he ran his small kirana store, was pacing, sweating more than usual. It wasn't the heat, it was the 'notice' from the Income Tax Dept. It was all greek to me then, a tangle of sections and clauses about something called ‘Service Tax’. Turns out, the department thought he hadn't properly accounted for taxes on some packaged goods he sold. The amount was a hefty ₹25,000, a fortune in those days.
normalised: The summer of two thousand and eight was a scorcher, and not just weather-wise. Papa, usually the picture of calm as he ran his small kirana store, was pacing, sweating more than usual. It wasn't the heat, it was the 'notice' from the Income Tax D-e-p-t. It was all greek to me then, a tangle of sections and clauses about something called 'Service Tax'. Turns out, the department thought he hadn't properly accounted for taxes on some packaged goods he sold. The amount was a hefty rupee twenty five thousand, a fortune in those days.

unnormalised: We lived in a small rented house in Meerut, and Papa barely made enough to keep us afloat. My elder sister was about to start college, and I was in class 10. The thought of adding another huge expense was crushing. Mom suggested talking to Mr. Sharma, the local accountant, known for his 'connections' and willingness to 'adjust' things. But Papa refused. He always believed in doing things the right way, even if it meant struggling.

But Papa refused. He always believed in doing things the right way, even if it meant struggling.

unnormalised: He spent days poring over tax documents, receipts, and ledgers, squinting under the dim light of a 60-watt bulb. He even bought a thick book on tax laws from the local bookstall, which he'd read late into the night. Seeing him so stressed, I tried to help, though I barely understood what a 'TIN number' even meant. I mostly fetched him chai and rubbed his back.

unnormalised: Finally, after weeks of agonizing, Papa decided to contest the notice. He wrote a detailed letter to the IT officer, explaining his understanding of the tax laws and pointing out discrepancies in the assessment. He attached all the relevant documents, every single receipt and invoice he could find. He even went to Delhi, spending ₹1500 on train tickets alone, to personally present his case.
normalised: Finally, after weeks of agonizing, Papa decided to contest the notice. He wrote a detailed letter to the I-T officer, explaining his understanding of the tax laws and pointing out discrepancies in the assessment. He attached all the relevant documents, every single receipt and invoice he could find. He even went to Delhi, spending rupee one thousand five hundred on train tickets alone, to personally present his case.

unnormalised: Weeks turned into months. We almost gave up hope. Then, one day, a letter arrived. The IT Dept. had reviewed Papa’s case and found merit in his arguments. They waived the penalty and reduced the tax amount to just Rs 5000. It was still a lot, but manageable. Papa let out a huge sigh of relief. He even offered me a Mithai, a rare treat.

unnormalised: That incident taught me a valuable lesson. Not just about the complexities of Indian tax law (which I eventually learned in law school!), but about integrity, perseverance, and the importance of standing up for what you believe in. And, yes, about the sometimes bewildering, but ultimately just, workings of the Income Tax Department of India under Section 80C and related circulars issued on 14/06/2007.
